channel.title: Digg Top Stories
channel.description: Digg - What the Internet is talking about right now

item.title: Rest In Peace, Roger
item.description: Roger Ebert, who was without question America's most prominent and influential film critic, has died.

item.title: Roger Ebert's Epic Takedown Of 'Transformers: Revenge Of The Fallen'
10 Movies Roger Ebert Really Hated
item.description: Roger Ebert passed away today at age 70. Back in 2010, Stacy Conradt rounded up some of his best bad reviews. Let's revisit those today as we mourn the first film critic to win a Pulitzer Prize and one of our favorite people on Twitter.

item.title: Never Lose The Most Important Photos – Or Videos – Again
item.description: We all have moments we want to remember for the rest of our lives, but we're not all keeping those memories safe. Picturelife makes showing and backing up all your photos and videos as easy as taking them. If you haven't given them a shot, here's your chance.

item.title: Roger Ebert On The Beauty Of The Rice Cooker
item.description: First, get the Pot. You need the simplest rice cooker made. It comes with two speeds: Cook, and Warm. Not expensive. Now you're all set to cook meals for the rest of your life on two square feet of counter space, plus a chopping block.

item.title: This Map Of America's Female Mortality Rates Is Pretty Terrifying
item.description: This map, via health researcher Bill Gardner, shows the change in mortality rate for females in each county in the United States between 1992 and 2006.

item.title: Classical Portraits Of Extreme Plastic Surgery
item.description: Phillip Toledano’s photos in his series “A New Kind of Beauty” have many traits of a traditional portrait, but his subjects are far from average. Toledano documents people who have gone through radical reconstructive plastic surgery.

item.title: Georgia High School Students Fight For First-Ever Integrated Prom
item.description: Wilcox County High School has two proms: one for white students and one for non-white students.

item.title: Being Gay At Jerry Falwell's University
item.description: A former student's account of coming out at Liberty University.

item.title: How To Hide $8.3 Billion
item.description: Matthew Taylor was able to amass an $8.3 billion long position before anyone else noticed in what are called “e-mini futures,” which bet that the S&P 500 will rise in the future. Unfortunately, that didn’t really work out for him, and now he’s probably off to jail.

item.title: Every Human Has A 'Breathprint' – What Does Yours Say About You?
item.description: The chemical signature in your breath is unique to you, and may even be as distinctive as your fingerprint. In fact, researchers think your "breathprint" could soon be used to determine your true identity, or diagnose you with an illness.

item.title: 'Game Of Thrones' Mnemonics For Character Names
item.description: No more looking like an idiot when you confuse Talisa with Khaleesi.

item.title: World's Largest Bitcoin Exchange: We Are Suffering A Massive Attack On Our Servers
item.description: Yesterday, the world's first and largest Bitcoin exchange, Mt. Gox, had an outage, and users couldn't access the trading platform. Now they've told the world what went wrong.

item.title: Meet The Foursquare Mayors Of Top-Secret Washington
item.description: Just because you work in or visit a highly classified, black-budget spy agency, doesn’t mean you can’t have mad Foursquare cred.

item.title: Here’s The Japanese Song So Offensive It Took North Korea’s Focus Off The U.S.
item.description: For the last two weeks, North Korean media has been wholly consumed with escalating tensions against the U.S., so the fact that they set aside an entire daily commentary for the song suggests that they might really, sincerely be incensed by it.

item.title: A Total Facebook-ification Of Your Phone
item.description: The social network dials up a new way to hook people on its mobile phone software.

item.title: How Far Those North Korean Missiles Can Actually Reach In One Map
item.description: So, how far can those missiles actually reach?

item.title: Being The Jew In The Box
item.description: To have conversations with Germans about Jews, I had to become an exhibition at Berlin’s Jewish Museum.

item.title: How Bad Is the Job Market For College Grads? Your Definitive Guide
item.description: Young bachelor's holders are hurting. But they're still doing better than high-school grads, and their crisis has been vastly overstated.

item.title: These Pictures Of A Human Tower Competition Are Insane
item.description: Photographer David Oliete got a pretty unique perspective in 2012, shooting the entire event at what appears to be a nearly aerial position.

item.title: Where Is the Most Expensive Place To Own a Car?
item.description: This chart shows the total cost of buying a family car (an average of low- and high-end brands) in selected cities in 2010, then running it for three years.

item.title: German Farm Tests Shooting As Alternative To Slaughterhouses
item.description: The experience of dying at a slaughterhouse is "an enormous ordeal" for cattle. A farm in northern Germany is proposing an alternative: shooting the livestock in the places they live. Many believe the method provides a stress-free death for the animals.

item.title: What It's Like To Be Kidnapped... For Fun
item.description: Why on earth would someone pay hundreds of dollars to fly halfway across the country for the pleasure of being abducted by thugs, handcuffed in a basement for hours, and forced to pee into a Gatorade bottle?

item.title: When Medical Literature Included Unicorns
item.description: "We know not the real truth of this matter to this day ..."

item.title: Why Evil Origin Stories Suck
item.description: When you have a built in audience, it’s far easier to get butts into seats. This has led to the rise of a particular kind of narrative – the “Evil Origin Story.” The formula is (theoretically) simple: take an iconic villain that people already love (to hate) and explain how they got to be that way.

item.title: Juggalos Are Humans Too
item.description: Sometimes it’s hard being a Juggalo. The media hates you. The band you love is, to many, nothing but a laughing stock. And recently, even the FBI classified your kind as a criminal gang.

item.title: Inside Apple's Plans For Its Futuristic, $5 Billion HQ
item.description: Most big construction projects tend to run a bit over budget and a bit behind schedule. Apple being Apple, this project is far bigger than most and therefore far over budget and behind schedule.

item.title: Armstrong To Make Another Comeback
item.description: Disgraced cyclist Lance Armstrong will make another comeback. But this time, it's in a sport you probably wouldn't guess.

item.title: China’s Secret Battlefields
item.description: Onlookers say it resembles the aftermath of a bombing raid—and it does, except bombs aren’t this precise.

item.title: The Week I Had HIV
item.description: Misdiagnoses are a rare but intractable problem. Here’s what happened to me.

item.title: How To Delete Your Digital Life
item.description: Wiping away your digital life means getting rid of the traces you've left – the mistakes you made, the embarrassing photos, the unwise comments, the flawed social media profiles where you've left too much visible. But it's not easy.

item.title: How Did Neo-Nazi Prison Gangs Become So Powerful?
item.description: Three US justice officials who tackled white supremacist prison gangs have been killed. Originally formed to fight other gangs, these groups are now accused of a range of criminal activities on the outside, from drug smuggling and kidnapping to murder. How did neo-Nazi prisoners set up huge criminal networks?

item.title: Yes, Healthful Fast Food Is Possible. But Is It Edible?
item.description: After the success of companies like Whole Foods and brands like Annie’s, there’s now a market for a fast-food chain that’s not only healthful and cheap, but good.

item.title: The True Science Of Parallel Universes
item.description: Here's a quick video explaining how parallel universes could work.
